title: What's the integral of the Poisson distribution formula? - Quora

response.answer_text: A variable x following a Poisson Distribution with parameter μ, is a discrete variable and assumes integer values on the +ve  axis of X. It represents " rare" events or occurrences and the probability p(x<=k ) is given by the summation,Being discrete variable , it is the summation and not an integral. That , probability is given by Σp(x), where you already have probability expression. With a known, μ or the best unbiased estimate of it. Where the limits on the summation is from x=0,1,2,3,4 .....k. For a large n, that is as n tends to infinity, the Poisson distribution tends to a Normal distribution. Which, by the way also involves an exponential function. You can look up the proof in any text book on Mathematical Statistics. In such a case, the probability can be approximated by the Normal, specifically from the probability tables of the Standard Normal Variate.

Assuming you meant integration w.r.t. [math]\mu>0[/math] (as otherwise I am misinterpreting the question), [math]x[/math] being a fixed nonnegative integer, [math]\int_0^\infty\dfrac{e^{-\mu}\mu^x}{x!}d\mu=1[/math] since the Poisson p.m.f. is also the Gamma([math]1,x+1[/math]) p.d.f. There is an interesting relationship between a Poisson distribution and a Gamma (not only Exponential) distribution as well. See Gamma distribution.  Can you try to prove it?
